plants.name: Dahlias
plants.description: Dahlias are bushy, tuberous plants native to Mexico, known for their striking, colorful flowers in a wide range of shapes and sizes. They thrive in late summer to autumn gardens, producing large blooms even as the days shorten.
plants.location: Temperate regions worldwide; originally Mexico and Central America
plants.funFact: Dahlias are Mexico's national flower and were once used as food by the Aztecs.

plants.name: Chrysanthemums
plants.description: Chrysanthemums are hardy perennial flowering plants popular in autumn gardens. They are known for their dense, pom-pom like flower clusters and are synonymous with fall in many temperate regions.
plants.location: East Asia, widely cultivated in temperate climates worldwide
plants.funFact: Chrysanthemums symbolize longevity and rejuvenation in many Asian cultures.

plants.name: Goldenrod
plants.description: Goldenrod is a wildflower common throughout North America, recognized for its tall spikes of small, bright yellow flowers. It often blooms in late summer and autumn, providing important nectar for pollinators preparing for winter.
plants.location: North America, especially eastern and central USA and Canada
plants.funFact: Goldenrod is wrongly blamed for allergies caused by ragweed, which blooms simultaneously.

plants.name: Japanese Maple
plants.description: While primarily admired for their striking autumn foliage, some species of Japanese maple produce small, delicate flowers in early to mid-autumn. These inconspicuous blooms attract pollinators and precede seed development.
plants.location: East Asia, widely cultivated in temperate gardens globally
plants.funFact: Japanese maple flowers are small and often overlooked but are essential for seed production.
